sen.j: 土蔵（どぞう）とは、日本の伝統的な建築様式のひとつで、外壁を土壁として漆喰などで仕上げられるもの。
sen.e: Storehouses ('dozo') are traditional Japanese architectural structures with outer walls made of mud and finished with plaster.
Storehouses ('dozo') are traditional Japanese architectural structures with outer walls made of mud and finished with plaster.
Dozo (storehouses) are traditional Japanese architectural structures with outer walls made of mud and finished with plaster.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 日常では単に蔵（くら）とよばれることが多く、この様式で作られた建物は土蔵造り・蔵造りなどといわれる。
sen.e: They are usually simply referred to as 'kura' (storehouse) and buildings constructed in this style are called 'dozo-tsukuri' or 'kura-tsukuri'.
They are usually simply referred to as 'kura' (storehouse) and buildings constructed in this style are called 'dozo-tsukuri' or 'kura-tsukuri'.
They are usually simply referred to as 'kura' (storehouse) and buildings constructed in this style are called 'Dozo-zukuri' or 'Kura-zukuri' (earthen-wall building style).

sen.j: 倉庫や保管庫として建てられるもののほか、保管庫と店舗を兼ねて建てられるものもある。
sen.e: As well as those built as warehouses or for storage, there are also some which were constructed with the dual function of storage and shop.
As well as those built as warehouses or for storage, there are also some which were constructed with the dual function of storage and shop.
As well as those built as warehouses or for storage, there are also some which were constructed with the dual function of storage and shop.

sen.j: 店舗・住居を兼ねるものは「見世蔵（店蔵）」と呼ばれることもあり、倉庫・保管庫として建てられるものとは分化して発展してきた。
sen.e: Buildings of this type which combine shop and dwelling are called 'mise-gura' and developed as an off-shoot of the original buildings built for storage.
Buildings of this type which combine shop and dwelling are called 'mise-gura' and developed as an off-shoot of the original buildings built for storage.
Buildings of this type which combine shop and dwelling are sometimes called 'misegura' and developed as an off-shoot of the original buildings built for storage.

tit.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 起源ははっきりとはしない。
sen.e: The origin is not clear.
The origin is not clear.
The origin is not clear.

sen.j: 中世にも町屋 (商家)などと共に建てられており、近世、鉄砲の伝来の影響により城郭にも防火・防弾のために漆喰大壁の技術が用いられ、30cm以上の分厚い壁を多用したことで安土桃山時代後期から江戸期前後の櫓や天守などの防御施設は土蔵造りとなった。
sen.e: They were also built in the Middle Ages together with tradesmen's houses (merchant's houses), and in modern times, with the arrival of firearms, lime plaster stud wall techniques were also used on castles for fire-proofing and bullet-proofing, and mud walls over thirty centimeters thick were extensively used on defensive structures such as guard towers and castle keeps from the late Azuchi-Momoyama period to around the Edo Period.

They were also built in the Middle Ages together with tradesmen's houses (merchant's houses), and in modern times, with the arrival of firearms, lime plaster stud wall techniques were also used on castles for fire-proofing and bullet-proofing, and mud walls over thirty centimeters thick were extensively used on defensive structures such as guard towers and castle keeps from the late Azuchi-Momoyama period to around the Edo Period.

They were also built in the Middle Ages together with tradesmen's houses (merchant's houses), and in modern times, with the arrival of firearms, lime plaster stud wall techniques were also used on castles for fire-proofing and bullet-proofing, and mud walls over 30 centimeters thick as Dozo-zukuri style were extensively used on defensive structures such as guard towers and turrets keep from the late Azuchi-Momoyama period to around the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降には、城郭で発展した技術も生かされ、火災や盗難防止のために盛んに建てられ、後に裕福さの象徴ともなった。
sen.e: From the Edo Period, the construction of storehouses for fire-proofing and theft prevention flourished, often with the adoption of techniques developed in castle construction, and this created an impression of affluence.

From the Edo Period, the construction of storehouses for fire-proofing and theft prevention flourished, often with the adoption of techniques developed in castle construction, and this created an impression of affluence.

From the Edo period, the construction of dozo for fire-proofing and theft prevention flourished, often with the adoption of techniques developed in castle construction, and this created an impression of affluence.

sen.j: 明治以降には、土壁の上に漆喰ではなくモルタルを塗り洋風に仕上げられることもあった。
sen.e: From the Meiji Period onwards, some mud walls were finished with mortar rather than lime plaster, creating a western look.
From the Meiji Period onwards, some mud walls were finished with mortar rather than lime plaster, creating a western look.
From the Meiji Period onwards, some mud walls were finished with mortar rather than lime plaster, creating a western look.

sen.j: また、土壁ではなく煉瓦や大谷石で造られたものもある。
sen.e: Again, some were constructed with bricks or Oya stone instead of mud walls.
Again, some were constructed with bricks or Oya stone instead of mud walls.
Again, some were constructed with bricks or Oya-ishi stone instead of mud walls.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 現在は、伝統的な外観を生かして、飲食店などの商業施設や博物館に転用されることもある。
sen.e: Nowadays, the storehouse construction techniques are used on restaurants, businesses and museums to create a traditional look.
Nowadays, the storehouse construction techniques are used on restaurants, businesses and museums to create a traditional look.
Nowadays, the dozo construction techniques are used on restaurants, businesses and museums to create a traditional look.

sen.j: 外観の仕上げは、大壁とし、土壁の上に漆喰総塗籠（しっくいそうぬりごめ）とするか、各種の板張りとされる。
sen.e: The outer finish is a stud wall finished on both sides, with plaster on top of the mud daub, or a variety of planks.
The outer finish is a stud wall finished on both sides, with plaster on top of the mud daub, or a variety of planks.
The outer finish is a stud wall finished on both sides, with plaster on top of the mud daub, or a variety of planks.

sen.j: 平瓦を張り、漆喰を板蒲鉾のように盛って固める海鼠（なまこ）壁などとすることもある。
sen.e: Some storehouses were finished with 'namako-tsukuri' in which rectangular plain tiles are fixed to the wall and fine plaster mounded up into the gaps between the tiles in a way which resembles the fishcakes called 'ita-kamaboko'..

Some storehouses were finished with 'namako-tsukuri' in which rectangular plain tiles are fixed to the wall and fine plaster mounded up into the gaps between the tiles in a way which resembles the fishcakes called 'ita-kamaboko'..

Some dozo were finished with 'namako-kabe' in which rectangular plain tiles are fixed to the wall and fine plaster mounded up into the gaps between the tiles in a way which resembles the fishcakes called 'ita-kamaboko.'

sen.j: 漆喰の壁には、左官職人が鏝によって文字や絵などを表現するレリーフ（鏝絵）を造られることもある。
sen.e: In some cases plasterers use trowels to create reliefs of pictures or words on the plaster walls.
In some cases plasterers use trowels to create reliefs of pictures or words on the plaster walls.
In some cases plasterers use trowels to create reliefs of pictures or words on the plaster walls.

sen.j: 現在では、木板の代わりにブリキや鉄製の板・波板を張ることがある。
sen.e: Nowadays, tinplate, steel plate or corrugated plate is used instead of wooden boards.
Nowadays, tinplate, steel plate or corrugated plate is used instead of wooden boards.
Nowadays, tinplate, steel plate or corrugated plate is used instead of wooden boards.

sen.j: 壁厚は約300mm以上あることが多く、開口部の外戸なども土戸（土と漆喰で戸の外部表面を覆ったもの）とすることがある。
sen.e: Most walls are over 300mm thick and the outer doors are also made of mud, with the outside of the doors coated with mud and plaster.
Most walls are over 300mm thick and the outer doors are also made of mud, with the outside of the doors coated with mud and plaster.
Most walls are over 300mm thick and the outer doors are also made of mud, with the outside of the doors coated with mud and plaster.

sen.j: 古くは江戸時代の大火、近代では空襲による大火でも、内部に火が回らない事例が多く、耐火性に関しては定評があった。
sen.e: The storehouses are noted for their fire resistance, with many examples in which the storehouses survived fires during the Edo period in which there were many great fires and also during the air raids in modern times.

The storehouses are noted for their fire resistance, with many examples in which the storehouses survived fires during the Edo period in which there were many great fires and also during the air raids in modern times.
It is noted for their fire resistance, with many examples in which the dozo survived fires during the Edo period in which there were many great fires and also during the air raids in modern times.

sen.j: ただし空襲で使用された焼夷弾とは屋根を貫通したあと内部で発火する兵器のため、屋根に焼夷弾が直撃した場合は、外壁は無事でも内部が焼け落ちたという例も多い。
sen.e: However, the fire bombs used in the air raids were weapons which caught fire after penetrating roofs, so in cases where the firebombs directly hit the roof, there were many examples in which the the outer walls remained intact, while the inside was burnt out.

However, the fire bombs used in the air raids were weapons which caught fire after penetrating roofs, so in cases where the firebombs directly hit the roof, there were many examples in which the the outer walls remained intact, while the inside was burnt out.

However, the fire bombs used in the air raids were weapons which caught fire after penetrating roofs, so in cases where the firebombs directly hit the roof, there were many examples in which the outer walls remained intact, while the inside was burnt out.
sen.cmt: 不要な語をのぞきました。

sen.j: またかつては、いざ近隣で火災が発生したという際、普段出入りの左官が駆けつけ、用意してある用心土と呼ばれる粘土を土蔵の全ての隙間に叩きつけ、土蔵への延焼を防ぐといった防火活動もあった。
sen.e: Again, in the past, whenever a fire broke out in the neighborhood, a plasterer going by would run in and use clay prepared for fire prevention purposes to block up all gaps and prevent the storehouse from catching fire.

Again, in the past, whenever a fire broke out in the neighborhood, a plasterer going by would run in and use clay prepared for fire prevention purposes to block up all gaps and prevent the storehouse from catching fire.

Again, in the past, whenever a fire broke out in the neighborhood, a plasterer going by would run in and use clay prepared for fire prevention purposes to block up all gaps and prevent the dozo from catching fire.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 古典落語ねずみ穴 貧乏暮らしから大店へ成功し、ある日、火の用心に、土蔵のねずみ穴と呼ばれる換気口だけを目塗しなかったために、全ての蔵が焼け落ちて、路頭に迷う場面がある。
sen.e: Japanese classic Rakugo called Nezumiana: There is a scene in which a person who moves from rags to riches with a large store, when one day, while fire-proofing, he neglects to cover the vent called a rathole, and the whole storehouse burns down, so he is turned out on the street.

Japanese classic Rakugo called Nezumiana: There is a scene in which a person who moves from rags to riches with a large store, when one day, while fire-proofing, he neglects to cover the vent called a rathole, and the whole storehouse burns down, so he is turned out on the street.

Japanese classic Rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) called Nezumiana (rat hall): There is a scene in which a person who moves from rags to riches with a large store, when one day, while fire-proofing, he neglects to cover the vent called Nezumiana, and the whole dozo storehouse burns down, so he is turned out on the street.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.e: There are quite a few examples of towns boasting streets with many storehouses as tourist spots.
There are quite a few examples of towns boasting streets with many storehouses as tourist spots.
There are quite a few examples of towns boasting 'streets with many kura storehouses' as tourist spots.

sen.j: 多くは、貯蔵用の土蔵ではなく、店舗・住居を兼ねた見世蔵である。
sen.e: Most of them are not storehouses for storage but mise-gura buildings which combine shops and residences.
Most of them are not storehouses for storage but mise-gura buildings which combine shops and residences.

Most of them are not dozo storehouses for storage but misegura buildings (a shop constructed using the fireproof system of construction known as dozo-zukuri style or kura-zukuri style) which combine shops and residences.
sen.cmt: 用語集より補足しました。

sen.j: 国登録有形文化財が100棟以上あり、その中に多くの土蔵建築が含まれている。
sen.e: There are more than one hundred buildings registered as national tangible cultural artifacts, and these include many buildings constructed with the mud-wall storehouse techniques (dozo-tsukuri).
There are more than one hundred buildings registered as national tangible cultural artifacts, and these include many buildings constructed with the mud-wall storehouse techniques (dozo-tsukuri).
There are more than 100 buildings registered as national tangible cultural properties, and these include many buildings constructed with the dozo techniques.

sen.e: It prospered as a base for water transport and a large number of mud wall buildings can be found in the area designated as an Important Preservation District for Groups of Traditional Buildings, and many old houses remain including the former house of Tadataka Ino.
